content: Lots of activity this weekend, much of it regarding builtin types
Also, I'm sure everyone has seen already, but the Chalk integration PR for rustc got merged :)

On the list for today:

  • Minutes updating on rust-lang/wg-traits (last is 2020.03.03)
    * Will also close meeting issues
  • Sprint overview
    * Blog post?
  • Next sprint planning
Anyways, I noticed that the minutes (https://github.com/rust-lang/wg-traits/tree/master/minutes) haven't been updated since March 3rd
Seems like it was a busy week!
heh, yeah, though I think our sprint docs are good
I've been meaning to get around to it, but haven't had time. Does anyone want to update them?
I'm figuring that when this sprint ends (... uh... today)
we would try to write that up in the form of a blog post / sprint report and commit to the repo
The current sprint runs from 2020.03.31 to 2020.05.12. You can find our sprint goals here.
(if nobody else wants to, I will)
maybe we should discuss next sprint plans? :)
@nikomatsakis see the agenda :sweat_smile:
in answer to your question about minutes, I know I won't be able to
I know @detrumi updated them the last time
but I do think it's worth (separately, not in this meeting probably...) discussing what kinds of minutes we want to keep
and how we can optimize the "cost" of doing so
I think that's worthwhile to talk about, even now
I personally am in favor of succinct minutes
I also am, esp. as we do everything on zulip
my main thought is that we should shoot to have a hackmd sort of thing that we use to drive things
i.e., we can capture it from time to time
so, for example, if someone goes through and wants to find discussion around a topic
it seems like for that goal, the ideal is probably tracking issues
i.e., you want it indexed by topic, right?
I think we're doing a pretty good job at keeping organized right now
I think the minutes we upload to wg-traits is really only for posterity
we could aggregate all the docs and such to the repo too
an ideal would be a sort of "table of contents" of topics covered at each meeting with links to where it "started"
(I wonder if it would even be good to concatenate all the docs into one page?)
that said, I'd sort of like to spend a bit of time in this meeting updating the sprint hackmd with our final status?
Yeah, the minutes themselves have been just a list of discussion points and the link
(to any of the new people, have you looked at previous minutes and were they helpful?)
I know personally, I have looked through the minutes, because I knew we talked about something but didn't remember when
grepping wg-traits zulip for keywords was more useful for me
(I've always found that it works quite well...)
The skill tree, sprint goals, and tracking issues / open issues have been helpful to me for checking on what is needed.
I haven't thought about looking through the past minutes, beyond the last few
I haven't found myself looking through them that much either, but I haven't really looked anywhere for decisions / rational for things yet
So I guess if this sprint is ending, do we know what is going to make up next sprint?
I think it'd be best to assess where we are first
I guess, hmm, I'll go back and write up the minutes for the past couple months and PR them
And we can decide over the next few days if there is anything else we want to do in addition
(I will say that the "agenda hackmd" was intended to be something we can just "copy-and-paste" into github, but I feel like it's not worked out that way)
(but if we tried harder to keep it updated ... it could be)
if we change our approach to minutes to have a "central page", we can even do the sync w/in hackmd
Looking at the sprint doc, we did really well :)
We made some progress on every goal
(gah, I see I owe @Areredify a review on https://github.com/rust-lang/chalk/pull/427 for some time now..sorry.. :blushing:)
I'd like to go goal by goal I think
to try and summarize where we're at and what's next?
One next step is probably to connect the rustc side to the new builtin chalk types (e.g., for refs, etc)
That's an easy one to do :) We're I think halfway there
/me goes to pull up the issue
the other side of this is completing the list
but I guess we can make the link even if there are gaps

• [x] scalar types:
    • [x] unsigned integer types (u32, u64, usize, etc)
    • [x] signed integer types
    • [x] bool
    • [x] char
  • [x] tuple types (parameterized by arity, so Tuple(usize))
  • [x] str -- see https://github.com/rust-lang/chalk/issues/437
  • [x] reference types & and &mut -- https://github.com/rust-lang/chalk/issues/438
  • [x] raw pointer types * const and *mut -- https://github.com/rust-lang/chalk/issues/439
  • [ ] array types (requires const work to land)
  • [x] slice type -- https://github.com/rust-lang/chalk/issues/440
  • [ ] FnDef
  • [ ] Closure
  • [ ] generator
The table in the chalk book has also been super helpful
So, I think for closure and generator, there's maybe a bit of design work here? Maybe.
Personally, I have no clue what it is going to take to add them
so, this work is basically "rounding out the rustc integration MVP"
i.e., it won't have "more capabilities than it did before"
Adding in generator and closures will add in more
Builtin trait support is getting added as we add more types
there are sort of "next gen" goals that perhaps come next
I forget, did we make a list of all the FIXMEs and shortcomings?
I suspect a good goal for next sprint would be to kind of close off the "most embarassing hacks" :)
I think maybe the next big thing to figure out in regards to rustc integration is float/int special handing
the biggest hack I can think of is the const bit
the other thing that I think is worth paying attention to is the handling of bound variables
but that's going to require some rustc hacking I think, primarily
currently we're doing some kind of expensive "renumbering" here to handle that
I guess another thing is region / outlives integration
Saw your comments, will talk async with you
(found your old branch, just gonna base off that)
OK. Seems like we can move to next item?
I think before we plan next sprint it'd be good to do a review of the FIXMEs etc
Goal: Plan for what const integration looks like
Uhh so I will make the pr with GenericArg tomorrow
we should probably open a tracking issue for that work
Yes, I was going to say that
I think we know what steps we need to take for that?
well we have a tracking issue for constants, but no issue for the GenericArg refactor I guess
or did I make one, I forget

Jack Huey said:

I think we know what steps we need to take for that?

this is the plan that @Areredify was referring to
So what are the next steps for that?
After merging generic arg const pr will be ready to be merged (after a review, of course)

Jack Huey said:

So what are the next steps for that?

Wait until tomorrow :)
Goal: Move towards alignment of rustc and chalk types, and towards extracting a shared library
So, most of the work here has been done on the Chalk side
also, the work we did in adding builtins and stuff
even if we listed it under rustc integration
Also part of this is bound regions and Params
I feel like a good goal for me would be to better enumerate some of the rustc-side changes here,
I feel like I might want to try experimenting with refactoring rustc a bit
/me will make work for ya', don't worry
I've been enjoying using vscode with rustc, I have to say
even though I do love me some emacs
So, summary for this goal: progress has been made, more to do :)

nikomatsakis said:

I've been enjoying using vscode with rustc, I have to say

and by extension, chalk! :)
So, we landed initial support a while ago
yeah, it seems like we kind of stalled out here
@detrumi seems to be busy recently
indeed, I've been meaning to check out that branch and provide some detailed feedback
it just needs an hour or something to get the context paged in
@detrumi mentioned that they were stuck on interactions around implied bounds
I feel like we should be able to not think about that yet
but like I said, have to read :)
Goal: progress towards removing leak check in rustc
late breaking news: I have some notes on how to do this from this morning I have to write-up
I spent a few hours thinking it through and I think we can take a few steps to unblock progress
is there any way we can port the backwards-compat issue to a chalk example
I was somewhat trying to do that
to try to better understand the problem
At the PR that is linked got merged
This is split up into a few parts
recursive solver is worth "promoting" perhaps, but we made a lot of progress there
promoting to its own goal, I mean :)
meh, I guess the current contents are up to date?
I feel like there's a bit of "sync" to figure out next steps here
I was going to say, we should open an issue, if there isn't one already, refactor out some of the potentially shared stuff between the recursive solver and chalk-engine

Jack Huey said:

I was going to say, we should open an issue, if there isn't one already, refactor out some of the potentially shared stuff between the recursive solver and chalk-engine

the "revisiting chalk-solve crate structure" question is going in this direction, too
I was thinking if maybe we want to merge chalk-rust-ir into chalk-solve
on another note, I've been wanting to catch up with @Florian Diebold to discuss how to separate the recursive solve to make it more parallel friendly and also how to handle salsa integration
And chalk-macros can just be merged into chalk-ir I think
I think merging chalk-rust-ir makes a lot of sense
I think I went a bit too far in the "lotsa crates" direction
i.e., you can't write a derive and use it from within the same crate
Proc macro crates can only export proc macros anyways, right?
unsure exactly what all else needs to be added
But I think this is good to discuss async
create a chalk file from any given program
yeah! there's still more to do but it's closer now
we've been trying to match playing catchup with the types added to chalk and adding actually new things
there's a checklist in the PR for what we believe needs to be done before it's no longer WIP / before it can be reviewed in full
I will dedicate some time this week to look at it
or did something get added to it
(well, more I've never really looked at it)
How helpful is that for actual benchmarks
I feel the answer is not very
or there would probably be more than one bench
But, other than actual benchmarks, work on the .chalk file writer
it's not really an interesting benchmark per se
it's just a case that we found was terrible at some point :)
I guess I should experiment with that branch
to get a feel for how the output looks/feels etc
I think it's maybe blocked on 1) Docs 2) Whether the dependency is okay
I have mixed feels about the dep -- I would like to align with rustc I guess
Not sure we have the time to discuss that now though
I think we did a lot here
I noted some things in the hackmd

• Added chalk big picture material
  • Moved content from rustc-dev-guide
  • Added table tracking the well-known traits
those were all 3 meant to be "things done"
I think the big picture material is "good enough" (to count as done:)
This is just a moving target though
for the last point, is it true that we're missing all the "auto traits"?
we should add those to the list of things to do for built-in types
yeah, auto trait support is lacking for builtin types
Let's also be sure to add enums/unions to builtin types
we probably want to align with that, and redefine the StructDatum to be more general?
Really, the only problem is how we handle auto traits
Or, not necessarily that it's a problem
I'm going to make a chalk issue for that right now
and fill in the details a bit later
We didn't get to next sprint planning
So, I think at minimum we want to wait another week to start
I was sort of expecting that we'll do that a bit async and use the next meeting to finalize? I guess we should decide whether we expect to have a blog announcing next goals by next week
or to plan the blog post in the next meeting
but do we maybe want to wait two weeks?
I think it's a good idea to use this week to finish up stuff and try to hvae a "rough draft" of next steps
and then we can finalize and try to announce the start for the week after
that'll give us some time to update the skill tree etc
and we've enough work on our plates as far as coding goes that I don't think we'll be running out
It's kind of shocking how much progress we're making :)
Yes, and lot's of new people around :)
We will be getting user reports on ices in chalk in no time
Side note, is there a way for me to use -Z chalk on all the ui tests?
I want to see how many of them pass

Jack Huey said:

Side note, is there a way for me to use -Z chalk on all the ui tests?

we should add a compare-mode
this allows the test suite to run with both modes
and give you a diff on the output
and we can also add .chalk.stderr files and so forth
but intended it for exactly cases like this
@Jack Huey I was wondering, where can I see the calendar with the upcoming meetings (the link in the repo does not seem to work for me)
This is the calendar with all compiler team meetings, including wg meetings

Jack Huey said:

detrumi seems to be busy recently

I just moved to a new appartment, and getting an internet connection set up is taking quite a while (I blame Corona), so I haven't had the chance to work on Impl Trait lately
